avalancheActivity.comment:
Persistent snowfall to below 1000 m. The wind will be moderate to strong in the vicinity of peaks.
Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. From early morning danger level 4 (high) will be reached at intermediate and high altitudes.

In particular in the vicinity of peaks and in gullies and bowls medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large slab avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of the easterly wind. Additionally avalanches can also be released in the old snowpack and reach large size.
Avalanches can in many places be released, even by a single winter sport participant. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are probable.

The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack are a clear indication of a weakly bonded snowpack.
The conditions are dangerous for backcountry touring outside marked and open pistes. The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Further increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. It is inadvisable to engage in backcountry touring in steep terrain.

snowpackStructure.comment:
20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 1500 m.
Sunday: 25 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1500 m.
At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular in the vicinity of peaks hardly any snow is lying. Adjacent to ridgelines on north, northeast and east facing slopes hard wind slabs formed.

The new snow will be deposited on a weakly bonded old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. The wind slabs of last week are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.

Reports filed by observers indicate the significant avalanche danger in particular above the tree line.

tendency.highlights: Monday: Snowfall to low altitudes. In some regions increase in avalanche danger in the course of the day. It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Heavy snowfall to above 900 m. The wind will be strong in the vicinity of peaks.

In the late morning danger level 4 (high) will be reached at intermediate and high altitudes.
In the typical avalanche paths the avalanches can reach fairly large size and in some places endanger transportation routes situated at relatively high altitudes.
In particular in the vicinity of peaks and on steep slopes medium-sized and, in many cases, large slab avalanches are possible as a consequence of the northeasterly wind,, also in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Additionally avalanches can also be released in the old snowpack and reach large size.

Whumpfing sounds and shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack are a clear indication.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are probable.
The avalanche prone locations are prevalent and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.

The conditions are dangerous for backcountry touring outside marked and open pistes. The current avalanche situation calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Further increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. It is inadvisable to engage in backcountry touring in steep terrain.

snowpackStructure.comment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and up to 40 cm in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1200 m.
30 to 50 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 1000 m.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed since Friday in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as above the tree line.
The wind slabs of last week are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
The new snow is lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.

Especially at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

tendency.highlights: Monday: Snowfall to low altitudes. Further increase in avalanche danger in the course of the day. From starting zones at higher altitudes large natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected. It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.

avalancheActivity.comment:
The southerly wind will transport the new snow.

In particular in the vicinity of peaks and in gullies and bowls small and medium-sized slab avalanches are possible. Additionally in some places avalanches can also be released in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant or triggered naturally.
Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack are a clear indication of a weakly bonded snowpack.

The wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in steep terrain. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs: Slab avalanches are the main danger.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Sunday: Little snow will fall.

At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular in the vicinity of peaks hardly any snow is lying. Adjacent to ridgelines on north, northeast and east facing slopes hard wind slabs formed.

The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on top of a weakly bonded old snowpack.
The wind slabs of last week are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.

tendency.highlights: The avalanche danger will persist. Monday: Some snow will fall in some regions. The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

avalancheActivity.comment:
Light snowfall above approximately 1200 m. The southerly wind will transport the new snow.
Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. They can be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size.
Avalanches can in isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
The wind slabs of the last few days are to be avoided in particular in steep terrain. Maintaining distances between individuals and one-at-a-time descents are recommended.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.

snowpackStructure.comment:
Sunday: Little snow will fall.

More recent wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. Adjacent to ridgelines on north, northeast and east facing slopes hard wind slabs formed.
Intermediate and high altitudes: Large-grained weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep shady slopes.

Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its surface, the snowpack is not homogeneous, and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases.

tendency.highlights: Monday: Down to low altitudes snow will fall in some regions. The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
